metadata.title: The Cyborg Developer: Empirical Analysis of Cognitive Extension Through Human-AI Collaborative Programming
metadata.description:
AI coding assistants are transforming software development, yet empirical understanding of how developers integrate these tools into cognitive workflows remains limited.

Through computational autoethnography, we analyze 802 collaborative sessions (85,370 messages, 27,672 tool invocations) across 47 projects over 30 days using Claude Code.

Key findings:

  • Delegation score of 0.71 — developers treat AI as cognitive extension, not autocomplete
  • 7.59× longer sessions with high-capability models — intentional model selection by task complexity
  • 2,846 messages per active day — sustained integration, not occasional assistance
  • 13.3 projects per week — fluid context-switching enabled by AI support

We introduce Cyborg Cognition — the integrated cognitive system formed when human direction-setting combines with AI information gathering and execution. This framework extends theories of distributed cognition (Hutchins) and extended mind (Clark & Chalmers) to human-AI programming collaboration.

Limitations include single-subject design; we provide sensitivity analyses and invite replication.
references: Clark, A., & Chalmers, D. (1998). The Extended Mind. Analysis, 58(1), 7-19.
Hutchins, E. (1995). Cognition in the Wild. MIT Press.
Haraway, D. J. (1991). A Cyborg Manifesto. In Simians, Cyborgs, and Women. Routledge.
Peng, S., et al. (2023). The Impact of AI on Developer Productivity: Evidence from GitHub Copilot. arXiv:2302.06590.
Da Silva, A. H. (2025). From Commits to Cognition: A Mixed-Methods Framework for Inferring Developer Mental Models. Zenodo. doi:10.5281/zenodo.18012186
metadata.notes: Preprint establishing priority for Cyborg Cognition framework. This paper extends the Developer Mental Model Framework (DMMF) from artifact analysis to real-time human-AI interaction analysis. Extended version with additional data forthcoming.
